summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. DiIorio to various recipients, including judges and the SEC, alleging widespread SEC corruption, obstruction, and facilitation of ongoing securities fraud. The emails detail allegations against specific SEC officials, financial entities like Virtu Financial (NITE), and individuals involved in alleged money laundering schemes through OTC market shells, with a focus on Riot Blockchain (RIOT) and its connections to Barry Honig and Russian entities.

persons.name: Christopher J. DiIorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of SEC corruption and securities fraud related to Knight Capital, Virtu Financial, Riot Blockchain, and various OTC market shells.

persons.name: Dougie Cifu
persons.context: Accused by DiIorio of knowingly lying about Virtu Financial's (NITE) equity market making share volumes to conceal illegal naked shorting and money laundering activities.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Repeatedly described as a 'prolific bag man' involved in multiple alleged money laundering shells, including MGT Capital, Bioptix, and Riot Blockchain.

persons.name: Mr. Gottschall
persons.context: An SEC official from the Denver office criticized for a supposedly inadequate investigation into Riot Blockchain (RIOT) and for not visiting its listed headquarters.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Named in SEC actions and alleged to be involved in fraud schemes with entities like NewLead and connections to Honig and Millenium Biotech/Inergetics.

persons.name: John M. Fife
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for unregistered penny stock dealing; alleged to be involved with MGT Capital and Iliad Research.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Charged by the SEC as an unregistered penny stock dealer; his actions are claimed by DiIorio to be based on his whistleblower information.

persons.name: Mark B. Fisher
persons.context: His firms were involved in an acquisition by Riot Blockchain; his Miami connections are questioned in relation to SEC official Eric Bustilloe.

persons.name: Dmitry Akhanov
persons.context: Identified as an insider in Bioptix/Alphasniffer (predecessor to RIOT) and a board member of NeoPhotonics, raising questions about Russian involvement.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: A healthcare fraud felon who was a large shareholder in Millenium Biotech/Inergetics, which was allegedly controlled by Barry Honig.

persons.name: Chad Readler
persons.context: Former DOJ prosecutor on the Brian Colleran civil case; later appointed as a federal judge by Trump.

persons.name: Eric Bustilloe
persons.context: Described as a 'grossly corrupt' SEC official, implied to have connections to Mark B. Fisher's Miami operations.

persons.name: Robert Eide
persons.context: Named in FINRA/SEC actions related to Aegis Capital; his pension plan was a seller in a SciSparc (formerly Therapix) offering.

persons.name: Kevin McKenna
persons.context: Named in SEC action for aiding and abetting Aegis Capital's violations.

persons.name: Ms. Pasquinelli
persons.context: Addressed in an email, questioned about why certain SEC actions based on DiIorio's information are not posted as whistleblower award eligible.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Addressed in an email, implored to send a subpoena to DiIorio regarding the Riot Blockchain fraud allegations.

persons.name: Judge Cote
persons.context: Criticized for the sentencing of Dan Kamensky, which DiIorio calls a 'gross miscarriage of justice' due to alleged corruption between the SEC and Jefferies/Handler.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Sentenced by Judge Cote; DiIorio alleges he was set up by Handler/Ressler (Jefferies/Ares Management) for interfering with their Neiman Marcus deal.

persons.name: Handler
persons.context: Alleged to have a corrupt relationship with the SEC and to have set up Dan Kamensky to protect a deal involving Ares Management and Neiman Marcus.

persons.name: Ressler
persons.context: Allegedly involved with Handler in setting up Dan Kamensky to protect the value of the Neiman Marcus asset for Ares.

persons.name: Searles
persons.context: SEC LA official accused of protecting UBS San Diego and related money laundering frauds, and of having no jurisdiction over UBS Weehawken correspondence.

persons.name: Banerjee
persons.context: SEC LA official, grouped with Searles, accused of protecting frauds and having no jurisdiction over certain UBS matters.

persons.name: Jason Sunstein
persons.context: San Diego resident and CFO of several OTC Pink sheet companies (Viper Networks, Santeon Group) alleged to be money laundering shells.

persons.name: Ashraf Rofail
persons.context: CEO of Santeon Group, an entity with African/Egyptian ties, operating from a San Diego virtual office.

persons.name: Chad Everett Harris
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of Northern Data's acquisition and sale of the Whinstone data center in Texas.

persons.name: Mathis Schultz
persons.context: Former private banker who founded Northern Data in 2015.

connections.description: DiIorio accuses Cifu, CEO of Virtu Financial (NITE), of knowingly lying about share volumes to conceal illegal naked shorting and money laundering.
Honig is alleged to have used Bioptix (which pivoted to become RIOT) as a money laundering shell and gained ownership in RIOT through a fraudulent offering.
Both are implicated in alleged money laundering schemes; Sason's entities held shares in Inergetics/Millenium, which Honig allegedly controlled.
Akhanov was an insider in Bioptix/Alphasniffer, a predecessor to RIOT, linking the Russian entity Rusnano USA to the company.
Colleran, a healthcare fraud felon, was a large shareholder in Millenium Biotech/Inergetics, which DiIorio alleges was controlled by Honig.
DiIorio implies a connection between Fisher's Miami operations and SEC Miami Director Eric Bustilloe, suggesting potential corruption.
Eide is the CEO of Aegis Capital Corp, which was subject to SEC/FINRA actions for violations.
Alleged to have worked together to set up Dan Kamensky to protect a Neiman Marcus deal involving Ares Management.
DiIorio accuses SEC official Searles of protecting UBS San Diego and related money laundering frauds.

events.title: Virtu Financial Q1 2021 Earnings Call
events.description: Virtu Financial CEO Dougie Cifu stated that April volumes were 'a hair under 10 billion shares per day.' DiIorio alleges this is a knowingly false statement to conceal much higher volumes from illegal naked shorting.

events.title: SEC Ends Investigation into Riot Blockchain
events.description: The SEC Denver office, via Mr. Gottschall, terminated its investigation into Riot Blockchain without recommending enforcement action. DiIorio claims the investigation was inadequate and never visited RIOT's listed headquarters.

events.title: Sale of Whinstone Data Center
events.description: Northern Data/Northern Bitcoin sold the Whinstone Texas data center in April 2021.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC filed charges against Joshua Sason and others for an elaborate microcap stock fraud. DiIorio claims this action was based on his whistleblower information.

events.title: SEC Charges Against John M. Fife et al.
events.description: The SEC charged John M. Fife and companies he controls for acquiring and selling over 21 billion shares of penny stock without registering as a dealer.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Justin W. Keener
events.description: The SEC charged Justin W. Keener (d/b/a JMJ Financial) as an unregistered penny stock dealer.

events.title: MEMX Exchange Launch
events.description: The SEC under Clayton allegedly gave Virtu Financial (NITE) and CDEL their own exchange, MEMX, to facilitate illegal naked shorting of OTC shells, according to DiIorio.

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher J. DiIorio, alleges the SEC is grossly corrupt and actively facilitates ongoing securities fraud by protecting entities like Virtu Financial (NITE) and Riot Blockchain (RIOT).

DiIorio claims Riot Blockchain (RIOT) is a money laundering shell connected to Barry Honig and Russian entities like Rusnano USA, and that its listed Castle Rock, CO headquarters does not exist as claimed in SEC filings.

The document alleges that Virtu Financial (NITE) conceals massive illegal naked shorting volumes in OTC markets, which constitute its core business, and that CEO Dougie Cifu knowingly lies about these volumes to the public.

Multiple SEC enforcement actions (against Joshua Sason, John Fife, Justin Keener) are claimed by DiIorio to be based on his whistleblower information, yet are allegedly not posted as award-eligible in an act of obstruction.

The emails suggest potential national security risks due to the involvement of Russian entities (Rusnano, Dmitry Akhanov) in U.S.-listed companies like Riot Blockchain and NeoPhotonics, facilitated by SEC inaction.
